text: {| class="infobox" style="font-size: 90%; width: 28em;" |colspan="2" style="background: #227799; text-align: center; color:#ffffff;"| XVIII Racquetball World Championships \- Colombia 2016 - |- style="vertical-align:top;" | Host | Cali, Colombia |- style="vertical-align:top;" | Dates | July 15 - July 23 |- style="vertical- align:top;" |colspan="2" style="background: #dfdfdf; text-align: center; color:#227799;"| Men's singles |- style="vertical-align:top;" |colspan="2" style="background: #dfdfdf; text-align: center; color:#227799;"| Women's singles |- style="vertical-align:top;" |colspan="2" style="background: #dfdfdf; text-align: center; color:#227799;"| Men's doubles |- style="vertical-align:top;" |colspan="2" style="background: #dfdfdf; text- align: center; color:#227799;"| Women's doubles |- style="vertical-align:top;" | Gold 10px | Aimee Ruiz & Janel Tisinger |- | Silver 10px | Paola Longoria & Samantha Salas |- | Bronze 10px | Jenny Daza & Adriana Riveros Frédérique Lambert & Jennifer Saunders |} The International Racquetball Federation's 18th Racquetball World Championships were held in Cali, Colombia from July 15 to 23, 2016. This was the first time Worlds have been in Colombia, and the first time the event was held in South America since 1998, when Cochabamba, Bolivia was host. In the final, Americans Aimee Ruiz and Janel Tisinger upset Mexicans Paola Longoria and Samantha Salas, who were the three time defending champions in Women's Doubles. Ruiz and Tisinger were silver medalists in 2014, when they lost to the Mexicans in the final. The win was Ruiz's third World Championship in Women's Doubles, as she also won in 2006 with Laura Fenton and 2008 with Jackie Paraiso. It was Tisinger's first World Championship. ==Tournament format== The 2016 World Championships was a two-stage competition. There was an initial group stage played as a round robin with the results used to seed teams for the medal round. ==Round robin==
